bibl.title: The Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion. (1861-65.)

taxonomy.bibl: Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion

keywords.term: fatal cases of diarrhœa and dysentery, with accounts of the morbid appearances observed
from Lincoln Hospital, Washington, D. C.
large intestine ulcerated throughout its entire length

revisionDesc.change: additional proofing of transcription and encoding, identified keyword terms
case text extracted and transformed from larger file

body.p: Case from the case-book of LINCOLN HOSPITAL, Washington, D. C.; Surgeon J. Cooper McKee, U. S. A., in charge.

CASE 423.—Private Martin K. Hendrick, company G, 16th Maine volunteers; age 43; admitted from the depot hospital of the 5th Corps, City Point, Virginia, May 5, 1865. Acute diarrhœa. Died, May 11th. Autopsy the same day: All the thoracic and abdominal viscera were healthy, except the intestines, particularly the large intestine, which was very much ulcerated throughout its entire length.—Acting Assistant Surgeon J. P. Arthur.
